thread.title: After yearlong wait, Yellowstone Christian ready for first game
thread.title_full: After yearlong wait, Yellowstone Christian ready for first game

author: JEFF BERSCH jbersch@billingsgazette.com
title: After yearlong wait, Yellowstone Christian ready for first game
text:
LARRY MAYER/Gazette Staff 
Yellowstone Christian College men's basketball coach Leonard Epps runs practice in the school’s gym last month. 
Over a year in the making, the day has finally arrived for Leonard Epps and his basketball team at Yellowstone Christian College. 
The basketball program, and athletics in general, will debut Wednesday night when YCC plays the first game in program history, a matchup against crosstown foe Rocky Mountain College. 
The Centurions and Battlin’ Bears will play at 7 p.m. at the Shrine Auditorium, a game Epps has been looking to since he took on the job of building the basketball team and athletics program in September of last year. 
“It’s just so exciting,” he said earlier this week. “It’s great to see all our hard work finally paying off. The guys are chomping at the bit. They’re ready to play someone other than ourselves.” 
YCC, a tiny Christian school on the west end of Billings, decided a few years ago to add athletics in an attempt to gain exposure and increase enrollment. Men’s basketball will be the first program off the ground. 
And the Centurions won’t start lightly. They will play a full schedule in their first season, opening against a Rocky program with tradition. The Bears won the 2009 NAIA national championship. 
YCC was accepted in June as a provisional member of the National Christian College Athletic Association. It gives the school an athletic affiliation and a region to call home as it begins college sports. 
“I came here in general, to Billings, Montana, to make this something special,” said Epps, a native of Louisville, Ky. “We want the community to be involved. We don’t want to play a soft schedule. We’d like to have a rivalry with Rocky and play every year. 
“We don’t want to be a team Rocky gets to warm up against. We have a lot of respect for them and I think they do for us. We’re taking this game as serious as we’ll take any game. I think we have a shot.” 
Epps, who played college basketball at York College in Nebraska, said his team will be uptempo, pressing on defense and getting shots up quickly. 
His team is young, so he said they'll lean on transfers Keegan Oyugi and Darius Jenkins on and off the court. Oyugi, a point guard, came from Garden City Community College in Kansas, and Jenkins transferred from York. 
Epps also said freshman Osondu Kelvin, a 6-foot-9 center and native of Nigeria, should be one of the team’s top players. 
“We have a lot of talent, but we’re young,” Epps said. “That talent should keep us in a lot of games against some of the better competition we’ll face early. I’d look for us to make some noise down the road.” 
While it’s the first game for YCC, the Bears already have played twice. They picked up two wins over the weekend at the Craig Finberg Memorial Tournament in Dillon. Tags
